name: Hardest Famous Hang-ups Trivia Quiz | TV & Movies Mixture | 10 Questions

questions.text: "I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it any more" was a memorable line from "Network". Who spoke the line?
questions.explanation:
Peter Finch.

	Paddy Chayefsky script. With Faye Dunaway. The line really caught on.

questions.text: The most famous compulsion in literature may be a "hand-washing compulsion". With what play by Shakespeare is it associated?
questions.explanation:
Macbeth.

	Lady Macbeth -trying futilely to wash away the blood and guilt.

questions.text: In "Vertigo", James Stewart had a fear of heights. Which of the following was true of his fear?
options: He  watched a policeman fall to his death
He nearly fell to his death while pursuing someone
His fear was a key reason that he was hired to investigate Mrs. Elster's strange behavior
questions.explanation:
All choices are true.

	Great classic by Hitchcock. One of his best.

questions.text: Rock Hudson starred in "Magnificent Obsession". He was obsessed with helping - specifically, with helping Jane Wyman. What was her problem?
questions.explanation:
Blindness.

	From the Lloyd C. Douglas novel. Not exactly mental illness, but ...Okay movie - despite the fact that there were enough suds here for several good-sized laundries.

questions.text: "Fear of Flying" was a best seller many years ago. Who was the author?
questions.explanation:
Erica Jong.

	It was considered "contemporary" at the time.

questions.text: In a classic play, one character was afraid of "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs". Who was the author?
questions.explanation:
William Inge.

	Inge's best play (in my opinion) dealt (in part) with fear of the unknown. Robert Preston was fine in the lead role - also with Dorothy McGuire and Angela Lansbury.

questions.text: Addiction is yet another type of problem. Who starred in "The Man With The Golden Arm"?
questions.explanation:
Frank Sinatra.

	Early Sinatra. Milland ("Lost Weekend") and Lemmon ("Days of Wine and Roses") starred in movies about alcohol addiction.

questions.text: In "Lolita", James Mason was obsessed with the title character. Who among the following was NOT in the movie?
questions.explanation:
Jason Robards.

	Lyon was Lolita. Winters was her mother. Sellers was Mason's "rival" (of sorts) for Lolita.

questions.text: In "The Collector" (by John Fowles), what did the title character collect?
questions.explanation:
Butterflies.

	Women, too - but why give away the story? Interesting novel and movie(with Terence Stamp and Samantha Eggar).

questions.text: Which of the following literary characters was NOT haunted by a feeling of guilt based on his involvement in causing the death of another person?
questions.explanation:
George Webber.

	Webber was the protagonist in "You Can't Go Home Again" (by Thomas Wolfe). His problems did not involve another person's death. Dorian Gray (in Oscar Wilde's "Picture of Dorian Gray") became a murderer. Raskolnikov (in Dostoevsky's "Crime and Punishment") was also a murderer. Clyde Griffiths was the protagonist in Theodore Dreiser's "An American Tragedy" (played by Montgomery Clift in the movie version "A Place in the Sun"). He was also involved in the death of another person.
